quote: Inspiration is for amateurs; the rest of us just show up and get to work. – Chuck Close
Inspiration exists, but it has to find you working. – Pablo Picasso
Done is better than perfect. – Sheryl Sandberg
One step at a time, you'll get there.
Every piece of art has an ugly stage. And the only way to get past it--is to keep working at it!
Create for you first. That way, there will always be at least one person who enjoys your work!
Who cares if no one else likes it, as long as you do.
A year from now you'll wish you started today. – Karen Lamb
Trust the process. It may look like crap now, but it'll get better.
The perfect is the enemy of the good. – Voltaire
Nothing is as scary as a blank canvas. Just get something down; you can fix it later.
It doesn't matter how the paint is put on, as long as something is said. – Jackson Pollock
Probably 90% of what any artist does is practice. – Dorianne Laux
No matter your level, someone out there wishes they were where you are now.
Ever tried. Ever failed. No matter. Try again. Fail again. Fail better. – Samuel Beckett
If I wait for inspiration to hit before I work, I'll get old waiting.
If you hear a voice within you say ‘you cannot paint,' then by all means paint, and that voice will be silenced. – Vincent van Gogh
We don't make mistakes – just happy little accidents. – Bob Ross
Every artist was first an amateur. – Ralph Waldo Emerson
Have no fear of perfection, you'll never reach it. – Salvador Dalí
You can't wait for inspiration, you have to go after it with a club. – Jack London
Don't think about making art, just get it done. Let everyone else decide if it's good or bad. While they are deciding, make even more art. – Andy Warhol
To practice any art, no matter how well or badly, is a way to make your soul grow. So do it. – Kurt Vonnegut
To create one's own world takes courage. – Georgia O'Keeffe
If people knew how hard I worked to get my mastery, it wouldn't seem so wonderful at all. – Michelangelo
An artist cannot fail; it is a success to be one. – Charles Horton Cooley
Great things are done by a series of small things brought together. – Vincent van Gogh
It took me four years to paint like Raphael, but a lifetime to paint like a child. – Pablo Picasso
I would rather die of passion than of boredom. – Vincent van Gogh
Learn the rules like a pro, so you can break them like an artist. – Pablo Picasso
Sucking at something is the first step to being sorta good at something. – Jake (Adventure Time)
It does not matter how slowly you go as long as you do not stop. – Confucius
The best time to plant a tree was 20 years ago. The second best time is now.
The expert in anything was once a beginner. – Helen Hayes
Don't compare your beginning to someone else's middle. – Jon Acuff
Slow progress is still progress.
I have not failed. I've just found 10,000 ways that won't work. – Thomas Edison
Do not fear mistakes. There are none. – Miles Davis
Practice isn't the thing you do once you're good. It's the thing you do that makes you good. – Malcolm Gladwell
You are allowed to be both a masterpiece and a work in progress simultaneously. – Sophia Bush
Continuous improvement is better than delayed perfection. – Mark Twain
Don't compare your progress to that of others. We need our own time to travel our own distance.
If you're walking down the right path and you're willing to keep walking, eventually you'll make progress. – Barack Obama
Keep going, and don't worry about your speed. You're making progress, even if it doesn't seem like it. Forward is forward, no matter how slow. – Lori Deschene
Failure is success in progress. – Albert Einstein
Be not afraid of going slowly, be afraid only of standing still.
The only time you should ever look back is to see how far you've come. – BTS
The elevator to success is out of order. You'll have to use the stairs... one step at a time. – Joe Girard
Amateurs sit and wait for inspiration, the rest of us just get up and go to work. – Stephen King
You can't use up creativity. The more you use, the more you have. – Maya Angelou
Motivation is what gets you started. Habit is what keeps you going. – Jim Rohn
The worst enemy to creativity is self-doubt. – Sylvia Plath
Genius is patience. – Isaac Newton
Adopt the pace of nature: her secret is patience. – Ralph Waldo Emerson
Do, or do not. There is no try. – Yoda
Whatever you're meant to do, do it now. The conditions are always impossible. – Doris Lessing
The one thing that you have that nobody else has is you – your voice, your mind, your story, your vision. So write and draw and build and play and dance and live as only you can. – Neil Gaiman
It ain't about how hard you hit; it's about how hard you can get hit and keep moving forward. – Rocky Balboa
I fear not the man who has practiced 10,000 kicks once, but the one who has practiced one kick 10,000 times. – Bruce Lee
Great works are performed not by strength, but by perseverance. – Samuel Johnson
The journey of a thousand miles begins with a single step. – Lao Tzu
If you're going through hell, keep going. – Winston Churchill
Imagination is more important than knowledge. Knowledge is limited; imagination encircles the world. – Albert Einstein
Experience is simply the name we give to our mistakes. – Oscar Wilde
If you're not making mistakes, then you're not doing anything. – John Wooden
Creativity is just procrastination in a fancy disguise.
Talent is a pursued interest. Anything that you're willing to practice, you can do. – Bob Ross
I am always doing that which I cannot do, in order that I may learn how to do it. – Pablo Picasso
Whether you think you can or you think you can't, you're right. – Henry Ford
Do one thing every day that scares you. – Eleanor Roosevelt
There is a crack in everything. That's how the light gets in. – Leonard Cohen
People often say that motivation doesn't last. Well, neither does bathing – that's why we recommend it daily. – Zig Ziglar
You don't have to be great to start, but you have to start to be great. – Zig Ziglar
Just keep swimming. – Dory (Finding Nemo)
The master has failed more times than the beginner has even tried. – Stephen McCranie
Blender was first created in 1994 by Ton Roosendaal inside the Dutch studio NeoGeo as an in-house tool for animation.
The name 'Blender' was inspired by a song by the Swiss electronic band Yello.

Not a Number (NaN), a company founded by Ton Roosendaal in 1998, was created to market and develop Blender commercially. NaN collapsed in 2002 when funding dried up, leaving Blender's future uncertain. The Blender community raised €110,000 in just seven weeks in the 'Free Blender' campaign of 2002, saving the software.
Blender's first open movie, 'Elephants Dream' (2006), was the world's first open-source animated short film.
The Argentinian feature film 'Plumíferos' (2010) was the first theatrical feature made entirely in Blender.
Netflix's 'Next Gen' (2018) was a feature film created entirely in Blender by Tangent Animation.
Spider-Man: Across the Spider-Verse (2023) used Blender's Grease Pencil for hand-drawn linework effects.
A fan-made LEGO Spider-Man sequence animated in Blender was included in 'Spider-Verse' (2023).
In 2025, the Latvian film 'Flow,' rendered in Eevee, won the Academy Award for Best Animated Feature.
BlenderArtists.org remains the largest dedicated forum for Blender users since the early 2000s.
In 2004, Blender was used for pre-visualization on Spider-Man 2, one of its first Hollywood credits.
Blender's transition from right-click select to left-click default in 2.8 was one of its most controversial changes.

NASA has used Blender for scientific visualization, including the 'Experience Curiosity' web app to showcase the Mars rover, and for visualizing global sea-level changes at the Scientific Visualization Studio during the pandemic.
Blender's open-source license ensures it will always remain free to use.
You can view all of Blender's Git history - including commits, diffs, authors, and branches - on the projects.blender.org Diffusion interface and via its public mirror on GitHub.
Blender's mascot Suzanne was once called the 'Hello World' of Blender renders.

Blender's free and open nature has inspired countless creatives to pursue 3D without financial barriers. While beveling an edge (Ctrl+B), press P to flip the curve direction to the inside, useful for smoothing classic elements like wall trims.
When adding a loop cut (Ctrl+R) and moving it, press E or F to match the cut's shape with one of the corners, helping create parallel cuts on the mesh.
Save selected vertices by creating a Vertex Group (plus button, assign) to easily re-select them later, enhancing workflow for complex models.
Hold ALT while changing a parameter (e.g., size, rotation) with multiple objects selected to apply the change to all of them at once.
When using planes as lights, prevent them from lighting their backside by connecting the Backface output of a Geometry node to the factor of a Mix Shader.
Enable Cavity (World or Screen) in Viewport Shading settings to enhance depth perception and clearly see details on your object's surface.
Center your view on selected objects or elements in any mode (Object, Edit, Outliner) by pressing Numpad Period (.).
Set your viewport to 'Orbit Around Selection' in Navigation preferences to rotate the view around your currently selected elements, across all modes.
Isolate selected objects for focused work by pressing Slash (/) to enter Local View; press again to exit without affecting other hidden objects.
Split your 3D viewport into four simultaneous views (perspective, top, front, right) by pressing Ctrl+Alt+Q, ideal for modeling from multiple angles.
Perform mathematical operations (e.g., '90 + 5' or '95 + 20 - 50 / 100') directly within any numeric input field in Blender.
Quickly reset a numeric value to its default (or zero) by hovering over it and pressing Backspace.
Access the relevant Blender Wiki documentation page for a specific feature by hovering over it and pressing F1 (requires internet connection).
In edit mode, quickly grow or shrink your selection by pressing Ctrl+Numpad Plus (+) or Numpad Minus (-).
Select all connected faces under your cursor by hovering over a mesh part and pressing L in edit mode.
Press G twice in edit mode to slide edges or vertices along existing surfaces without deforming the mesh.
Randomize the location, rotation, or scale of multiple objects by selecting them and going to Object > Transform > Randomize Transform.
Add frequently used modifiers or functions to your Quick Favorites menu by right-clicking them and selecting 'Add to Quick Favorites'; access them quickly with the Q key.
Quickly rename selected objects by pressing F2.
Perform batch renaming of multiple objects or data types by selecting them and pressing Ctrl+F2.
Rotate your view while holding Alt to quickly snap to orthographic views, even without a numpad.
In Blender 4.5+, switch the display graphics backend to Vulan in preferences for improved viewport and file loading performance.
Reduce file size by going to File > Cleanup > Purge Unused Data to remove any unnecessary data from your blend file.
Copy and paste color values between color pickers on the same screen by dragging and dropping, or use Ctrl+C / Ctrl+V for pickers on different screens.
Navigate your scene like a video game using Walk or Fly mode (Shift+Tilde), with W,A,S,D to move and mouse to look around.
Winsor McCay's 'Gertie the Dinosaur' (1914) helped invent character animation by giving a drawn dinosaur a distinct personality.
Max Fleischer invented the rotoscope in 1915, letting animators trace live action for smoother, more realistic motion.
Lotte Reiniger's 'The Adventures of Prince Achmed' (1926) is the oldest surviving animated feature, crafted with silhouette cut-outs.
Disney's 'Steamboat Willie' (1928) popularized synchronized sound in cartoons and launched Mickey Mouse to stardom.
Disney's 'Flowers and Trees' (1932) was the first Technicolor cartoon and the first animated short to win an Oscar.
'Tin Toy' (1988) became the first CGI film to win an Academy Award, a preview of Pixar's future.
Pixar's 'Toy Story' (1995) was the first feature-length film made entirely with CGI.
'Toy Story 2' (1999) was accidentally deleted mid-production-rescued by a home backup from a technical director.
The Academy Award for Best Animated Feature debuted in 2001; 'Shrek' won the inaugural Oscar.

Blender is the world's most powerful free 3D creation tool, built entirely by volunteers and community funding. If Blender has been a significant part of your creative journey, please consider donating to the devfund using the donate button below!

Unlike other industry tools that cost thousands, Blender is free forever. It is the support of this awesome community that keeps it in development and helps it grow. If you are in a financial position to support this awesome tool, please consider donating to the fund using the link below.

Blender's development fund directly supports programmers that help develop it and advance it at such a quick rate. Every donation translates into more tools for creators worldwide. So please consider donating. Even if it's a single dollar!

When you donate to Blender, you're not just funding software-you're funding freedom, creativity, and access for millions of artists world-wide. If you haven't already, please consider donating to the blender dev fund.

Think of the last Blender tutorial that inspired you-it exists because Blender itself exists. Donations make that inspiration possible. If you are in the financial position to support a tool like blender, consider donating to the blender dev fund using the link below!

A small donation from you could mean a massive impact for the blender community--faster updates, better tools, and a stronger Blender for the future. If you haven't already, please consider donating to the blender dev fun.

Blender is free for you-because several others donated to the dev fund to keep it free. If you have the financial resources to pass that support on, please click on the donate button below to make a donation to the blender dev fund!

Was it not work learning to ride a bike, even though you can drive anywhere. Every creative skill, every techinical tool learned will just improve you as an artist. So yes, Blender is, and will always be totally worth learning!

Do not wait to strike till the iron is hot; but make it hot by striking. – William Butler Yeats
Happiness is neither virtue nor pleasure nor this thing nor that but simply growth. We are happy when we are growing. – William Butler Yeats
Do not pray for an easy life, pray for the strength to endure a difficult one. – Bruce Lee
Be like water making its way through cracks. Do not be assertive, but adjust to the object, and you shall find a way around or through it. – Bruce Lee
The successful warrior is the average man, with laser-like focus. – Bruce Lee
The future depends on what you do today. – Mahatma Gandhi
Strength does not come from physical capacity. It comes from an indomitable will. – Mahatma Gandhi
Live as if you were to die tomorrow. Learn as if you were to live forever. – Mahatma Gandhi
A creative man is motivated by the desire to achieve, not by the desire to beat others. – Ayn Rand
The question isn't who is going to let me; it's who is going to stop me. – Ayn Rand
Man's greatness lies in his power of thought. – Blaise Pascal
Small minds are concerned with the extraordinary, great minds with the ordinary. – Blaise Pascal
All of humanity's problems stem from man's inability to sit quietly in a room alone. – Blaise Pascal
Others have seen what is and asked why. I have seen what could be and asked why not. – Pablo Picasso
Only put off until tomorrow what you are willing to die having left undone. – Pablo Picasso
Quality is not an act, it is a habit. – Aristotle
The roots of education are bitter, but the fruit is sweet. – Aristotle
Pleasure in the job puts perfection in the work. – Aristotle
Even the darkest night will end and the sun will rise. – Victor Hugo
Imagination is everything. It is the preview of life's coming attractions. – Albert Einstein
Try not to become a man of success, but rather try to become a man of value. – Albert Einstein
In the middle of difficulty lies opportunity. – Albert Einstein
A person who never made a mistake never tried anything new. – Albert Einstein
Champions keep playing until they get it right. – Billie Jean King
Pressure is a privilege. – Billie Jean King
Victory is fleeting. Losing is forever. – Billie Jean King
Change your life today. Don't gamble on the future, act now, without delay. – Simone de Beauvoir
To win without risk is to triumph without glory. – Pierre Corneille
All greatness of character is dependent on individuality. – James Russell Lowell
The art of life is to know how to enjoy a little and to endure much. – William Hazlitt
A wise man will make more opportunities than he finds. – Francis Bacon
Believe you can and you're halfway there. – Theodore Roosevelt
Keep your eyes on the stars, and your feet on the ground. – Theodore Roosevelt
Order and simplification are the first steps toward mastery. – Thomas Mann
A man is but the product of his thoughts. What he thinks, he becomes. – Mahatma Gandhi
You may never know what results come of your actions, but if you do nothing, there will be no result. – Mahatma Gandhi
Courage isn't having the strength to go on - it is going on when you don't have strength. – Napoleon Bonaparte
The more I read, the more I acquire, the more certain I am that I know nothing. – Voltaire
Judge a man by his questions rather than by his answers. – Voltaire
Work banishes those three great evils: boredom, vice, and poverty. – Voltaire
You must do the things you think you cannot do. – Eleanor Roosevelt
The future belongs to those who believe in the beauty of their dreams. – Eleanor Roosevelt
With the new day comes new strength and new thoughts. – Eleanor Roosevelt
Great minds discuss ideas; average minds discuss events; small minds discuss people. – Eleanor Roosevelt
The dreamers of the day are dangerous men, for they may act on their dreams with open eyes. – T. E. Lawrence
The only limit to our realization of tomorrow will be our doubts of today. – Franklin D. Roosevelt
When you reach the end of your rope, tie a knot in it and hang on. – Franklin D. Roosevelt
The best way to predict the future is to create it. – Peter Drucker
Knowledge has to be improved, challenged, and increased constantly, or it vanishes. – Peter Drucker
Follow effective action with quiet reflection. From the quiet reflection will come even more effective action. – Peter Drucker
You shouldn't dream your film, you should make it! – Steven Spielberg
My imagination won't turn off. I wake up so excited I can't eat breakfast. – Steven Spielberg
All good ideas start out as bad ideas, that's why it takes so long. – Steven Spielberg
Filmmaking is all about appreciating the talents of the people you surround yourself with. – Steven Spielberg
Audience members are only concerned about the story. They'll be drawn to the story, not the technology. – Steven Spielberg
You can't start a movie by having the attitude that the script is finished. Your movie is finished before the first day of shooting. – Steven Spielberg
As a child, I always drew funny creatures... But I think the trick is not to grow up, not to learn to be an adult. – Tim Burton
Everything's a story, everyone's got stories... to me, the big nut to crack is how to tell a story, what's the right way to tell a particular story. – Ethan Coen
It's most important to just throw yourself into it, putting everything into the project you're working on. – Christopher Nolan
A camera is a camera, a shot is a shot. How you tell the story is the main thing. – Christopher Nolan
I've always believed that if you want to make a great film, not just a good film, you have to take a lot of risks. – Christopher Nolan
More important, for an aspiring filmmaker, is reading. Read, read, read. If you don't read, you'll never make a great film. – Martin Scorsese
You are going to have to take all of the responsibility... you're going to get all of the blame, so you might as well have made all of the decisions. – Francis Ford Coppola
No form of art goes beyond ordinary consciousness as film does, straight to our emotions, deep into the twilight room of the soul. – Ingmar Bergman
Filmmaking is a chance to live many lifetimes. – Robert Altman
For me, the great joy is to watch an audience watching what I've made. – Alfred Hitchcock
I just love photographing things and putting them together to tell a story. – Gordon Willis
I've always believed that true cinema is cinema of the imagination. – Orson Welles
Everybody has talent, it's just a matter of moving around until you've discovered what it is. – George Lucas
I want my audience to be constantly captivated, bewitched, so that it leaves the theatre dazed, stunned to be back on the pavement. – Federico Fellini
It's the same thing as how you get to Carnegie Hall: practice, practice, practice. Get a hold of a video camera and just shoot as much as you can. – Martin Scorsese
My advice to young filmmakers is this: don't follow trends, start them! – Quentin Tarantino
The director is the final author. Many of the best films ever made can be seen without dialogue and be perfectly understood. – Alfred Hitchcock
The director's taste and imagination play a crucial role in making a film. Is it meaningful? Is it believable? Is it interesting? These must be answered several hundred times a day. – Akira Kurosawa
If you get an impulse in a scene, follow it. It might be something. And if it ain't – take two! – Jack Nicholson
The essence of cinema is editing. It's the combination of extraordinary images of people during emotional moments, put together in a kind of alchemy. – Francis Ford Coppola
Make visible what, without you, might perhaps never have been seen. – Robert Bresson
If it can be written, or thought, it can be filmed. – Stanley Kubrick
Now before shooting anything, watch your movie in your head. Picture the scene... and then make your shot list. Now get each shot and cross it off the list. – Ridley Scott
Every scene has been done before. The idea is to photograph it better than what's already there. – Stanley Kubrick
Have u watched 'District 9'? It's a gritty sci-fi film by Neill Blomkamp with groundbreaking VFX and realistic alien design, showing how creative CGI on a modest budget can earn Oscar nods.
Have u watched 'The Creator'? It's a recent sci-fi thriller by Gareth Edwards with epic AI warfare visuals. Its imaginative tech and Oscar-nominated VFX make it a high-tech spectacle for any artist.

Have u seen 'Ex Machina'? This sleek sci-fi thriller features a realistic AI robot (Ava) brought to life with stunning effects, winning the Oscar for Best Visual Effects in 2013, a masterclass in subtle CGI blending.

Have u seen 'Flow'? It's a beautiful wordless animated adventure of a cat drifting through a flooded world. With its lush hand-drawn style and no dialogue, it shows how powerful visual storytelling alone can be. Made in Blender, Won the Oscan Recently. Check It Out!

Have u watched 'Meet the Robinsons'? A heartwarming Disney sci-fi about time travel. Its bright, futuristic CG world and the 'Keep Moving Forward' spirit make it inspiring for inventors and animators alike.
Have u seen 'Cats Don't Dance'? A fun 1930s Hollywood animated musical. Its charming 2D animation and catchy song-and-dance numbers make this often-overlooked gem burst with creative energy.

Have u watched 'The Iron Giant'? This cult classic is a 2D animation with heartfelt storytelling. Its gorgeous hand-drawn visuals and a giant robot hero show the power of art direction and character design.

Have u watched 'Song of the Sea'? It's a stunning Irish animated fairy tale with beautiful watercolor-style art. The mythic story and rich visuals make it a dreamlike experience for any artist's inspiration.

Have u watched 'Wolfwalkers'? An enchanting Irish animated adventure with a wild folk-art style. Its expressive hand-drawn characters and magical setting show how unique techniques can create truly magical worlds.

Have u watched 'Who Framed Roger Rabbit'? It's a groundbreaking mix of live-action and hand-drawn cartoon (with lots of famous Toons!). Its seamless blending of VFX and classic animation is a landmark in visual storytelling.

Have u watched 'Fantasia'? Disney's 1940 animated classic set to classical music. Its abstract, imaginative segments (like dancing mushrooms and swirling stars) show how animation can paint sound very inspiring visuals!

Have u seen 'Atlantis: The Lost Empire'? A lesser-known Disney sci-fi adventure. Its art direction was inspired by comic artist Mike Mignola, giving Atlantis a unique look great for seeing how strong design can shape a film's world.

Have u watched 'Yellow Submarine'? The Beatles 1968 psychedelic animated movie. Its mind-bending, colorful art style is like an animated acid trip an absolute classic for any artist seeking surreal visual inspiration.

Have u watched 'Paperman'? It's a Disney short blending hand-drawn and CG (Oscar-winner). This black-and-white 7-min love story proves simple sketchy lines and subtle animation effects can be incredibly charming and inspiring.

Have u watched 'Big Buck Bunny'? A hilarious 10-min CG short (Blender Open Movie) where a giant bunny takes on some forest bullies. It's proof that even an independent team using free tools can create fun, high-quality animation.

Have u seen 'Elephants Dream'? The first Blender Foundation open movie (2006) with surreal visuals. Its strange, abstract style is a great example of experimental CGI, reminding artists that animation can tell weird and wonderful stories.

Have u watched 'Caminandes: Llama Drama'? This short (by Blender Studio) has a clever llama vs. penguin chase. It's simple and funny, showing how humor and polish in animation can shine through even in a short clip.

Have u watched 'Caminandes: Gran Dillama'? The sequel to Llama Drama more hilarious adventure of the same llama. It's another polished short proving that creative stories (even with a silly llama) can come alive in CG.

Have u watched 'La Luna'? A dreamy Pixar short where a boy and his family sweep stars off the moon. Its painterly, storybook visuals and gentle magic prove that even a simple concept can be richly beautiful.

Have u seen 'Prospect'? A gritty indie sci-fi about a father-daughter mining crew on an alien moon. Its moody lighting and practical-set feel (with creative VFX) show what a creative low-budget production can achieve.

Have u seen 'Fantastic Mr. Fox'? Wes Anderson's quirky stop-motion (2009). Its meticulously styled sets and witty character animation prove how handcrafted visuals and auteur style can create a unique animated world.

Have u seen 'Okja'? A 2017 film (Netflix) about a girl and her mutant pig. It mixes real locations with impressively realistic CGI creatures inspiring for how to blend visual effects into a heartfelt story.
Titanic (1997) had a budget of $200 million and eventually grossed around $2 billion worldwide.
Cameron built an enormous practical Titanic set at Baja Studios, including full-scale ship models and gimbals for sinking scenes.
With later re-releases, Titanic became the second film ever to gross over $2 billion (it was the first to surpass $1 billion).
Avatar (2009) was nearly 70% computer-generated, and winning the Oscar for Best Cinematography was notable because most of what audiences saw was CGI.
James Cameron spent about 15 years developing the technology for Avatar, including co-inventing the ‘Fusion' 3D camera rig for deep 3D effects.
During Avatar's production, Cameron used a virtual cinematography system: a video-game style controller let him move a camera through the CGI scene in real time.
For Avatar: The Way of Water, Cameron built a 120×60×30 foot water tank (over 250,000 gallons) to shoot real water interactions with actors.
In Avatar 2, all actors and crew held their breath underwater (no scuba gear allowed) because air bubbles would break the motion-capture tracking.
Avatar 2 used two stacked motion-capture volumes-one above water, one below-and blended the data in real time so performances aligned seamlessly.
James Cameron's ‘Virtual Camera' workflow allowed him to watch actors perform as their Na'vi characters on monitors in real time.
Weta Digital's Gollum was one of the first CG characters meant to blend into live-action as a full-fledged actor rather than a monster.
Weta constructed Gollum with a full internal skeleton and muscle rig, so when he moved the CG skin would deform realistically.
Weta gave Gollum extraordinarily detailed eyes-about 5,000 polygons per eye, roughly a quarter of all Gollum's geometry-to achieve realistic eye depth.
During Jurassic Park (1993) filming, a real hurricane struck the Hawaiian set and actual storm footage was used in the film's storm scenes.
Only about 15 minutes of Jurassic Park's 128-minute running time actually showed full-size practical dinosaurs-the rest relied on close-ups or CGI to manage costs.
The terrifying velociraptor noises in Jurassic Park were created from mating tortoises' screeches and horses' panting sounds.
In The Matrix (1999), the iconic 'bullet time' camera move was achieved by surrounding Neo with a rig of still cameras triggered in sequence.
Weta FX delivered over 1,500 VFX shots for Kingdom of the Planet of the Apes (2024), with about 33 minutes of it being entirely CG environments and characters.
For the Apes film, actors wore upgraded mocap suits with embedded infrared LEDs so they could perform outdoors in sunlight.
A deep-learning facial solver was used to map actor expressions onto ape faces automatically, freeing animators to focus on nuances in the POTA series!
Harry Potter combined practical creature builds and CGI. For Chamber of Secrets (2002), a full-size Dobby model was built for the actors to look at.
In Prisoner of Azkaban, Weta Workshop built three animatronic hippogriff models-standing, rearing, and lying down-with individually applied feathers.
For Deathly Hallows – Part 2 (2011), 140 makeup artists turned 60 actors into goblins in just four hours, using about 1.7 tons of silicone prosthetics across the series.
Aragog the spider in Chamber of Secrets had a 5.5-meter legspan, took 15 puppeteers to operate, and its hair was glued bristle by bristle.
The Hobbit trilogy was shot natively in 3D, so on set Jackson's crew could watch monitors in real time with 3D glasses.
VFX artist John Berton Jr. admitted that The Mummy Returns' Scorpion King effect looked terrible partly because they had almost no reference scans of Dwayne Johnson's face.
Avengers: Endgame (2019) had a reported production budget of about $356 million and grossed $2.799 billion worldwide.
Avatar's $2.923 billion gross on a $237 million budget means it earned roughly 12.3× its production cost.
Weta VFX supervisor Eric Saindon noted that light reflecting under Gollum's semi-translucent skin was an innovation never done before on a CG creature.

checkout this awesome film called 'Spring' by 'Andy Goralczyk' - A poetic story of a shepherd girl and her dog who face ancient spirits to continue the cycle of life. This visually stunning short film was made entirely in Blender 2.8 and showcases beautiful animations.

checkout this awesome film called 'Agent 327: Operation Barbershop' by 'Hjalti Hjálmarsson' - A 3-minute teaser based on Dutch artist Martin Lodewijk's classic comics. Features secret agent 327 in a stylish action-comedy adventure with incredible animation quality.

checkout this awesome film called 'Coffee Run' by 'Javi Jealmerson' - The story of a woman fueled by caffeine, running through bittersweet memories of her past relationship. A unique loop-oriented short film with clever storytelling.

checkout this awesome film called 'Sprite Fright' by 'Matthew Luhn & Hjalti Hjálmarsson' - An 80's-inspired horror comedy set in Britain. When rowdy teenagers trek into an isolated forest, they discover peaceful mushroom creatures that turn out to be an unexpected force of nature.

checkout this awesome film called 'CHARGE' by 'Rik Schutte' - In an energy-scarce dystopia, an old destitute man breaks into a battery factory but finds himself confronted by a deadly security droid with no way out.

checkout this awesome film called 'Big Buck Bunny' by 'Sacha Goedegebure' - A comedy about a fat rabbit taking revenge on three irritating rodents. This classic short film showcases cartoon-style animation and has become a standard for video testing.

checkout this awesome film called 'Cosmos Laundromat' by 'Mathieu Auvray' - On a desolate island, suicidal sheep Franck meets his fate in a quirky salesman who offers him the gift of a lifetime. An absurdist science fantasy with stunning visuals.

checkout this awesome film called 'Tears of Steel' by 'Ian Hubert' - A sci-fi film set in dystopian Amsterdam where warriors and scientists gather at the Oude Kerk to save the world from destructive robots. Combines live-action and CGI.

checkout this awesome film called 'Sintel' by 'Colin Levy' - An epic fantasy tale where a girl befriends a baby dragon. After the little dragon is taken from her violently, she undertakes a long journey that leads her to a dramatic confrontation.
checkout this awesome film called 'Wing It!' by 'Blender Studio' - A fun and stylized cartoon that explores the polarized relationship between a cat and a dog aboard an out-of-control space shuttle.

checkout this awesome film called 'Alike' by 'Daniel Martínez Lara & Rafa Cano Méndez' - A thought-provoking story about a father and son living in a society where creativity is being choked out. Made by ex-animation students with no budget over 5 years.

checkout this awesome film called 'I Lost My Body' by 'Jérémy Clapin' - An Oscar-nominated French animated film about a solitary hand trying to reconnect with its owner. Made using Blender with 2D elements added through Grease Pencil.

checkout this awesome film called 'The Missing Scarf' by 'Eoin Duffy' - Albert the squirrel searches for his missing scarf in this dark comedy exploring life's common fears. Narrated by George Takei and shortlisted for Academy Awards.

checkout this awesome film called 'Celsius' by 'Stache' - A 35mm summer-themed short film exploring different perspectives on summer through various symbolic shots, from poverty to wealth, representing the human experience.

checkout this awesome film called 'The Drink' by 'William Landgren' - A playboy robot millionaire goes on a brief trip to buy motor oil. Created by 16-year-old filmmaker with incredible attention to 1960s film photography aesthetics.

checkout this awesome film called 'VOLTA' by 'William Landgren' - A cyberpunk-inspired visual journey exploring constant flow of ideas and complexity. Created with influence from Ash Thorp and Colorsponge's work.

checkout this awesome film called 'Impetus' by 'William Landgren' - An exploration of unpleasantness and loneliness through highly detailed and technical 3D environments. Every shot crafted with meticulous attention to composition and color.

checkout this awesome film called 'Untitled Spaces' by 'William Landgren' - A passion project combining architecture, interior design, and cinematography. Inspired by mid-century architectural magazines with vintage film characteristics and CMYK printing effects.

checkout this awesome film called 'Crest' by 'Dylan Donaldson' - The shortest film in many lists at 40 seconds, yet manages to open up a world of fantasy by giving incredible attention to detail in world-building.

checkout this awesome film called 'Swing to the Moon' by 'ESMA Students' - Winner of Best Student Project at SIGGRAPH 2023. A beautifully crafted student film showcasing advanced character animation and storytelling techniques.
checkout this awesome short series called 'Dynamo Dream' by 'Ian Hubert'

checkout this awesome film called 'Freelance' by 'Lollypop Man' - A recent 2024 animated short film that has gained attention in the Blender community for its professional quality and engaging storytelling.
checkout this awesome film called 'Alike' by Daniel Martínez Lara & Rafa Cano Méndez, a tender father-son story about creativity vs. conformity that went viral for its heart and simplicity.
checkout this awesome film called 'Darrel' by Marc Briones & Alan Carabantes, a snappy subway flirtation between two chameleons that escalates into elastic, expressive comedy.
checkout this awesome film called 'The Box Assassin' by Jeremy Schaefer, a kinetic action comedy where a pizza delivery collides with a legendary hitman in cartoony, punchy CG.
checkout this awesome film called 'Watermelon Girl' by SouthernShotty, an indie Blender short that leans into stylized characters, handcrafted vibes, and a long-form personal story.
checkout this awesome film called 'HOLD FAST' by Sam Scott-Thorne, a Blender animated Star Wars fan short that nails tone with clean staging and sharp space-opera beats.
checkout this awesome film called 'Relic – Part 1' by Curious Refuge, a Blender Star Wars fan film that blends ship exteriors and stylized planet vistas with grounded character moments.
checkout this awesome film called 'Rangers On Patrol' by Aaron Hunter, a Blender-made Star Wars fan short with crisp ship animation and old-school adventure energy.

checkout this awesome film called 'Glass Half' by Blender Studio (Beorn Leonard), a fast, funny 2D/3D NPR short about art snobs and perspective.
